bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, August 22, 1911

div1.p: Carter stresses to his daughter that every effort should be made to get her well. He also discusses his next foreign detail and how he will rise to the challenge.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, August 22, 1911
div1.opener:
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH AND MARINE-HOSPITAL SERVICE,
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND,
Louisville, Ky
Aug 22, 19011.
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
I enclose a letter of Dr. Wymans rec'd
yesterday. I answered it yesterday & also wrote
Glennan asking (1) if the detail were temporary
or permanent. I am reasonably sure the latter: (2)
when I w'd be expected to leave, telling him that
I had intended to get leave go on to Balt; & put
put you in Thayer's care & remain until you
got well. Thayer however will not return un-
til about October 1st so the Hos'l wrote me
Mchae is in his place. He was House Physici-
an after Futcher & Asst. House when I was there
in 1900, & is an able man.

I do not exactly know what is best to be done
(1) Whether, supposing as seems probable, that we all
go, the detail is more or less permanent, we all
you, your mother & I, (Ned is a separate problem) go
on
on & take our chance of getting you well over there
or (b) leave you here, say under Kinyoun's care, to
go to Thayer when he returns. get well & then
follow us or (c) go now, I coming on, Mchae get his
diagnosis & advice & deca matter I suppose of 5 to
possibly 15 days & on that decide whether (a) or (b) is
most advantageous. I can possibly tell better when I
hear from Glennan. I want you to get well, no inconveni-
ence is too great: no annoyance too much to undertake
to get well.

It had pleased me best to have had this
aidnotice in March next. Then there had please
God been no problem connected with either
Ned or yourself. He told me yesterday that he
thought he had passed the 600 word test you know
thatthe test is not read in class now
now
but transcribed at
once, so he cannot def-
initely tell untill
Mr. Mayor passes on the
transcription. He asked
me to call him up
at recess today to ask. So I hope
for the best. There is
a 4th letter to write
he said & he doesn't
know whether he
has the other three, or
some of them, to write
over as Mr. M. has not
told him. This however
is a minor thing
compared with the
United States Public Health and Marine-Hospital Service,
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND,
, 190
Surgeon.
SUBJECT:
NO. OF INCLOSURES,
Medical Off 600 word test. Also he says
Mr. M. lost his “big Billing sheet” &
unless it can be found he will have
to do it over. This is not improbable, as simi-
lar things happened. He ought to go to a
Sanitarium for a month after he leaves
College before he goes to work as& I will
try to arrange it for him.

I am going to Dr. White (for an extra pair
of glasses) today.

I wish this thing had come 6 months later,
or not at all. The last I sh'd not say as
it gives me another chance to do a man's
work & I will, please God, rise to the ne-
cessity when it arrives.

I do not think, “living expenses”means
includes those of my family, i.e., I would
get just what I get on any special detail.
Whether the service give me my foreign
commulation $90. per month I do not
know
know. If not I will get less than I w'd on
a regular foreign detail. However it is a ques-
tion of service not of pay.
